title: 105_s2152
content: The Act may be cited as the "Microcredit for Self-Sufficiency Act of 1998". Congress finds that over 1 billion people in the developing world live in severe poverty, with high child mortality rates and preventable deaths from malnutrition and disease. Women in poverty face greater workloads and fewer opportunities compared to men. Nearly 33,000 children die daily from preventable malnutrition and disease. Women in poverty have heavier workloads and limited access to education and economic opportunities compared to men. Directly assisting the poorest, especially women, in developing countries positively impacts family incomes, child nutrition, health, and education. The poor in developing nations, especially women, lack stable employment and social safety nets. Many poor women in developing countries lack stable employment and social safety nets, leading them to turn to self-employment for income. However, they struggle to access credit at reasonable rates to grow their businesses, trapping them in poverty. Many poor individuals struggle to access credit at reasonable rates to build their asset base or expand self-employment activities. They are forced to pay high interest rates to money lenders. An international Microcredit Summit aimed to expand access to credit for the world's poorest families, especially women, by 2005. The Microcredit Summit aimed to provide access to credit and financial services to 100 million of the world's poorest families, particularly women, by 2005. This initiative would benefit nearly half of the world's 1 billion absolute poor by enabling them to expand their incomes and businesses through self-sustaining microcredit programs. Microcredit programs through organizations like Grameen Bank and Accion International have successfully provided loans to the very poor, with repayment rates averaging 95 percent or higher. These programs help reduce poverty by giving access to loans at reasonable interest rates. Microcredit institutions like FINCA have high repayment rates, reducing poverty and dependency on foreign assistance. Interest income from loans can cover institutional costs, ensuring long-term sustainability. Loans are recycled, leveraging foreign assistance resources for new benefits to participants. In 1994, AID launched a Microenterprise Initiative in consultation with Congress to expand funding for sustainable microcredit institutions that provide credit, training, and mobilize domestic savings for poverty reduction and economic development. In 1994, AID launched a Microenterprise Initiative with Congress to expand funding for microcredit institutions. The Initiative aimed to support programs providing credit to the poorest with loans under $300. Funding for microenterprise activities fell to $111,000,000 in fiscal year 1996, with only 39 percent supporting these programs. Increased investment in microcredit institutions serving the poorest is crucial to achieving the Microcredit Summit's goal. AID's funding for microenterprise activities in the developing world should be expanded to $160,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 to align with the growing capacity of microcredit institutions. The Microcredit Summit's goal is to expand AID's funding for microenterprise activities in the developing world to $160,000,000 for fiscal year 1999. This will parallel the growing capacity of microcredit institutions and help reach tens of millions of the poorest with microcredit. The Microcredit Summit aims to increase funding for microenterprise activities to $160,000,000 in 1999, focusing on institutions serving the poorest. To reach millions of the poorest with microcredit, successful microcredit institutions need to expand and replicate. PVOs and NGOs have shown competence in developing networks of local microcredit institutions to help the very poor achieve financial stability. PVOs and NGOs have expertise in establishing networks of local microcredit institutions to assist the very poor in achieving financial sustainability. AID should prioritize investing in these organizations through its central funding mechanisms to expand successful microcredit institutions. By prioritizing investment in PVOs and NGOs through AID's central funding mechanisms, successful microcredit institutions can be expanded globally to provide financial services to the world's poorest families. AID can lead in supporting microenterprise for the poorest and improve coordination efforts at the operational level to promote best practices. The Act aims to expand AID's support for microenterprise development for the poorest by improving coordination efforts and promoting best practices in providing financial services. It also focuses on making microenterprise development a key component of AID's economic growth strategy. The Act aims to expand AID's support for microenterprise development by making it the centerpiece of the economic growth strategy. It also focuses on increasing assistance for providing credit to the poorest sector in developing countries, especially women. It also focuses on increasing assistance for providing credit to the poorest sector in developing countries, especially women. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "AID" refers to the United States Agency for International Development. The terms "microcredit", "microenterprise", "poverty lending portion of mixed programs", and "mixed programs" are defined under the 1994 Microenterprise Initiative of AID. "PVOs and other nongovernmental organizations" include private voluntary organizations. The term "PVOs and other nongovernmental organizations" refers to private voluntary organizations and international, regional, or national nongovernmental organizations active in the region or country where the project is located, with the capacity to develop and implement microenterprise programs for the poor, especially women. SEC. 4. MICROENTERPRISE ASSISTANCE. The President, through the Administrator of AID, is authorized to establish programs for microenterprise assistance in developing countries. Programs will be carried out by US PVOs and other organizations, including credit unions and private financial intermediaries. Eligibility criteria will be established by the Administrator of AID. The Administrator of AID will establish eligibility criteria for United States PVOs and indigenous organizations to provide microenterprise assistance in developing countries. Criteria will include access to formal financial sector and targeting the poorest individuals. The criteria for providing microenterprise assistance in developing countries include access to the local formal financial sector, targeting the poorest individuals, working directly with poor women, and implementing a plan for financial self-reliance through realistic interest rates. Funding levels for Fiscal Year 1999 will be allocated accordingly. Funding levels for Fiscal Year 1999 will allocate at least $160,000,000 for microenterprise assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, focusing on financial self-reliance through realistic interest rates. The funds authorized under this Act will be in addition to funds for microenterprise activities in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in fiscal year 1999. At least $80,000,000 of the funds will be used to support poverty lending. The funds authorized under this Act will be used to support poverty lending in the Former Soviet Union, Asia, and the Near East. Additionally, at least $35,000,000 will be provided for support of United States PVOs and indigenous nongovernmental organizations. Not less than $35,000,000 will be provided through AID for United States PVOs and nongovernmental organizations, with $10,000,000 allocated for the matching grant program. The matching grant program of AID supports United States PVOs by providing funds for poverty lending in low-income countries. The matching grant program of AID supports United States PVOs by providing funds for poverty lending in low-income countries, including loans of $300 or less in 1997 United States dollars to members of the poverty target population or for institutional development of entities engaged in poverty lending programs. The term "poverty target population" refers to the poorest 50 percent of individuals living below the poverty line as defined by the national government of the foreign country receiving funds. SEC. 5. PROGRAM PERFORMANCE CRITERIA. The Administrator of AID is required to strengthen mechanisms for microenterprise programs and develop systems for monitoring the impact of assistance under section 4. The Administrator of AID is tasked with targeting microcredit to the poorest population and establishing a monitoring system to measure the impact of assistance and make recommendations for adjustments to benefit the very poor, especially women. The Administrator of AID is required to monitor the amount of microenterprise credit and loans provided to the poverty target population to assess project effectiveness and make recommendations for enhancing assistance to benefit the very poor, particularly women. The Administrator of AID shall monitor microenterprise credit and loans to the poverty target population, report to Congress annually on progress. The Administrator of AID is responsible for monitoring microenterprise credit and loans under $300 to the poverty target population. They must report annually to Congress on the progress of achieving the Microcredit Summit goal of expanding access to financial services to 100 million of the world's poorest families by 2005. Additionally, a summary of the collected information is included in AID's annual presentation to Congress.
